name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Methods in Neuroscience
base_name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Methods in Neuroscience
long_desc: This course is a unique introduction to research in neuroscience for students by students. Here well talk about the hidden curriculum of research, how is neuroscience research done, rather than what have researchers discovered. This metaknowledge course is meant to prepare you for three specific goals 1 Find research methods that align with your interests and skills, 2 Be able to make informed decisions about your research path and 3 Inform you about possible research paths at CMUPitt

custom_fields.goals: The students learn how to formulate scientific questions, in particular how to differentiate between a sciencerelated question, a broad scientific question and a specific scientific question. Combining this with knowledge about the different available methods will equip students with the tools they need to start designing research projects.
custom_fields.key_topics: Main methods in neuroscience research: In-vivo electrophysiology, slice physiology, two-photon microscopy, fMRI, fNIRS, mathematical methods, behavioral analysis.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge:
Basic biology: Central dogma of biology, basic understanding of proteins.
Physics: Basic understanding of electricity (charged particles), basic understanding of optics (frequency/wavelength of photons)
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Each student will identify 2-3 science-related questions at the beginning of the semester. After a few methods have been presented to the class, the students will complete an assessment in which they make both broad and scientific questions that align with the recently presented methods. They will receive feedback after each assessment and each new assessment one will require them to improve on their answers provided in the previous one. This class will not have exams, these assessments are more than enough to engage the students in their educational growth.
custom_fields.relevance: This course will be relevant for first-year neuroscience graduate students (primary target) and senior undergraduate students (secondary target) because it will help them understand the field of neuroscience in terms of how does the research work look like and how each method impacts the possible research avenues with any given broad research question.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Optionally (yet to be set up) each method will be accompanied with a sample dataset for the students to use. An extra data-analysis session might be included to walk through data processing basics with students.
